H0.text: Leslie should not follow the experimental instructions exactly, as the teacher meant she should take a flexible approach to solving problems.

H1.text: Leslie should only write down lab results that seem to be correct, reflecting her teacher’s instruction to take a flexible approach to solving problems.

H2.text: Leslie should accept all scientific theories even if they have been proven wrong is what the teacher most likely meant when she told Leslie to take a flexible approach to solving problems.

H3.text: Leslie should be willing to consider many possible causes for her observations, as her teacher likely meant by urging her to take a flexible approach to solving problems.

A4.text: The scientific method is iterative. At any stage, it is possible to refine its accuracy and precision, so that some consideration will lead the scientist to repeat an earlier part of the process.

A5.text: He writes that in his work on new theories of international trade he reviewed prior work with an open frame of mind and broadened his initial viewpoint even in unlikely directions.

A6.text: The ability to critically analyze an argument — to dissect structure and components, thesis and reasons — is essential. But so is the ability to be flexible and consider non-traditional alternatives and perspectives.
